conclusion: Determine the potential difference between points a and b on the circular ring when it is partially inside the magnetic field.
Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction states that an emf is induced in a conductor when there is a change in the magnetic flux through the conductor.
The induced emf can be calculated using the formula: E = -dΦ/dt, where Φ is the magnetic flux.
The angle ∠aOb is 90°, forming a quarter-circle inside the magnetic field.
The magnetic flux Φ through the part of the loop inside the magnetic field is given by Φ = B · A.
The area A of the quarter-circle is A = (1/4)πR².
The rate of change of the area A is dA/dt = v · R.
The rate of change of the magnetic flux is dΦ/dt = B · v · R.
Using Faraday's Law, the induced emf E is E = -B · v · R.
The potential difference between points a and b is equal to the induced emf, so V_ab = B · v · R.
The potential at point b is higher than at point a.
Final answer: V_ab = B · v · R.
